leg:heading.title: DEFAMATION [rr 15.19–15.32]

p.text: [Div 4 insrt Amendment 5 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[4], effective 1 January 2006]

The Defamation Act 2005 applies to the publication of defamatory matter after the commencement of that Act. The Act commenced on 1 January 2006. However, the Defamation Act 1974 (as in force before its repeal by the Defamation Act 2005) continues to apply to the following causes of action by virtue of clause 2 (Application of this Act) of Schedule 4 (Savings, transitional and other provisions) to the Defamation Act 2005:
a cause of action for defamation that accrued before 1 January 2006,
a cause of action for defamation that accrued after the commencement of the Defamation Act 2005, but only if:
the action is raised in proceedings that include other causes of action that accrued before 1 January 2006, and
the action accrued no later than 12 months after the earliest pre-1 January 2006 action accrued, and
each action in the proceedings arose out of the publication of the same, or substantially the same, matter on different occasions.

Clause 2 of Schedule 4 to the Defamation Act 2005 also ensures that any other law (both legislative and common law) that would have applied to such causes of action but for the enactment of the new Act will continue to apply to such causes of action.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.19] r 15.19 Particulars in relation to statements of claim for defamation (cf SCR Part 67, rule 12; DCR Part 49, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to statements of claim for defamation (cf SCR Part 67, rule 12; DCR Part 49, rule 11)

p.text: The particulars required by rule 15.1 in relation to a statement of claim seeking relief in relation to the publication of defamatory matter must include the following:
particulars of any publication on which the plaintiff relies to establish the cause of action, sufficient to enable the publication to be identified,

particulars of any publication, circulation or distribution of the matter complained of or copy of the matter complained of on which the plaintiff relies on the question of damages, sufficient to enable the publication, circulation or distribution to be identified,

if the plaintiff alleges that the matter complained of had a defamatory meaning other than its ordinary meaning — particulars of the facts and matters on which the plaintiff relies to establish that defamatory meaning, including:
full and complete particulars of the facts and matters relied on to establish a true innuendo, and
by reference to name or class, the identity of those to whom those facts and matters were known,

if the plaintiff is not named in the matter complained of — particulars of identification of the plaintiff together with the identity, by reference to names and addresses or class of persons, of those to whom any such particulars were known, and
particulars of the part or parts of the matter complained of relied on by the plaintiff in support of each pleaded imputation.

Such of the following as is applicable must be filed and served with a statement of claim seeking relief in relation to the publication of defamatory matter (or any amended statement of claim) and be referred to in the statement of claim or amended statement of claim:
a legible photocopy of the original publication or, in the case of an internet, e-mail or other computer displayed publication, a printed copy,
a typescript, with numbered lines, of:
if the original publication is in English—the text of the original publication, or
otherwise — a translation of the text of the original publication.
Subrule (2)(b) must be complied with in respect of radio and television publications.

The particulars should include the persons to whom, dates when, and places where the defamation was published: Bradbury v Cooper (1883) 12 QBD 94 ; Clarke v Lees (1896) 12 WN (NSW) 137. Sufficient particulars of publication are provided when the matter complained of is alleged to have been published in a newspaper if the particulars refer to a named newspaper identifying the date of the edition containing the matter together with particulars that the newspaper was circulated in New South Wales and other states and territories of Australia: Singleton v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 20 February 1980, unreported, BC8000040); Lazarus v Deutsche Lufthansa AG (1985) 1 NSWLR 188 at 192 . Where a plaintiff relies upon extrinsic facts which are not generally known then particulars of publication to persons who had knowledge of those facts may be ordered where the particulars may be relevant to establish a particular defence or to quantify the appropriate amount of a payment into court: Fullam v Newcastle Chronical and Journal Ltd [1977] 3 All ER 32; [1977] 1 WLR 651 at 656, 659 ; Hughes v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (1985) 3 NSWLR 504 . A plaintiff who can establish the likelihood of a particular type of publication may be entitled to obtain discovery of the details of the publication in order to able to provide the required particulars: Kaiser v George Laurens (NSW) Pty Ltd [1982] 1 NSWLR 294 (publication by credit agency); Ahmed v John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 11; BC200600202 (international publication by newspaper).

level.toc-caption: [15.19.10] The statement of claim — pleading the place of publication

heading.title: The statement of claim — pleading the place of publication

p.text: Both the common law and the provisions of the Defamation Act permit a plaintiff who has pleaded a single cause of action against a newspaper to recover ordinary compensatory damages for the injury to his reputation caused by the entire issue of that newspaper published by the defendant, irrespective of whether the publication occurred either wholly or even partly within the state in which the action is brought: Toomey v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 173 ; Jones v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (1992) 26 NSWLR 732 . See also McKain v RW Miller & Co (SA) Pty Ltd (1991) 174 CLR 1; 104 ALR 257 . The place of publication is sufficiently by separate allegations (a) that the defendant published the matter complained of in a specified edition of a named newspaper on a particular date, and (b) that the newspaper was circulated in New South Wales and in each of the other states and territories of Australia: Singleton v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 20 February 1980, unreported, BC8000040) at pp 5–6, distinguishing O'Brien v Canberra Broadcasters Pty Ltd (ACTSC, Connor J, 13 March 1979, unreported).

level.toc-caption: [15.19.15] The statement of claim — photocopies and annexures

heading.title: The statement of claim — photocopies and annexures

p.text: It is unsatisfactory pleading to annex a photocopy of the page of the newspaper upon which the matter complained of appears. In the very limited cases where, by reason of the length of the matter complained of, it may be appropriate to plead in this way, care must be exercised that irrelevant matter is excluded from those photostat copies. It is also necessary that the photostat copy be clear, sharp and legible: Redmond v Advertiser-News Weekend Publishing Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 20 February 1980, unreported) at pp 1–2; Stewart v Shoalhaven & Nowra News Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 26 September 1980, unreported) at pp 1–2.

The extrinsic facts relied upon to identify the plaintiff in a defamation action should be given as particulars in the statement of claim, and not pleaded as material facts: Turner v Bulletin Newspaper Co Pty Ltd (1974) 131 CLR 69 at 80; 3 ALR 491 and Dawson Bloodstock Agency Pty Ltd v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 733 at 736 . The extrinsic acts relied upon may be asserted to be within the general knowledge of the community or, alternatively, as giving rise to a true innuendo: Hughes v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (1985) 3 NSWLR 504 ; Lewis v Daily Telegraph Ltd [1964] AC 234 at 281 .

The extrinsic facts relied upon to give the matter complained of a secondary or extended meaning must be stated in the particulars as facts; it is not sufficient compliance with the requirements of Pt 67 r 12(c) merely to identify newspaper articles in which those facts are referred to in some way: Stewart v Shoalhaven & Nowra News Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 26 September 1980, unreported). A true innuendo — that is, a secondary or extended meaning of the matter complained of — must be based upon existing facts: Grubb v Bristol United Press Ltd [1963] 1 QB 309 at 328–9 ; Mirror Newspapers Ltd v World Hosts Pty Ltd (1979) 141 CLR 632 at 641–2; 23 ALR 167; BC7900010 . The existence of the extrinsic facts must be proved and a plaintiff must also establish that they were known to at least one person to whom publication was made: Consolidated Trust Co Ltd v Browne (1948) 49 SR (NSW) 86 at 89; 66 WN (NSW) 7 at 8 ; Hughes v Mirror Newspapers Ltd (1985) 3 NSWLR 504 . Their existence is not proved by the mere tender of a newspaper in which they are stated. Statements made in newspapers which have not been either published by the defendant (and thus constituting an admission by him or her) or expressly or by implication adopted by the defendant are not themselves extrinsic facts upon which a true innuendo can be based: Astaire v Campling [1965] 3 All ER 666; [1966] 1 WLR 34 at 39–41 , so that identification of newspaper articles alone will provide inadequate particulars of true innuendo.The position relating to particulars of a true innuendo is to be contrasted with the giving of particulars of the extrinsic facts upon which identification may be based. Although such extrinsic facts must still be proved in evidence: Steele v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 348 , the plaintiff is nevertheless for this purpose entitled to rely upon material published in newspapers prior to the publication of the matter complained of, whether or not published by the defendant, as showing the condition of the public mind: Van Ingen v Mail & Express Publishing Co (1898) 50 NE Rep 979 at 981–2; Astaire v Campling, above,at 39, as well as upon matter published in newspapers after the publication of the matter complained of, provided that it was published by the defendant (thus again constituting an admission): Ware v Associated Newspapers Ltd (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 180 at 184 , see also Grapelli v Derek Block (Holdings) Ltd [1981] 2 All ER 272; [1981] 1 WLR 822 ; Hayward v Thompson [1982] QB 47; [1981] 3 All ER 450 .

The natural and ordinary meaning of the published words may convey a defamatory imputation. But words are often capable of conveying more than one ordinary meaning, and in such a case, the particular defamatory meaning contended for is regarded as a “false innuendo”: Petritsis v Hellenic Herald Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 174 at 191 ; Mann v Mackay Television Ltd [1992] 2 Qd R 136 at 142–3 ; Chakravarti v Advertiser Newspapers Ltd (1998) 193 CLR 519 at 579; 154 ALR 294 at 340; [1998] HCA 37; BC9801849 per Kirby J. And it was common practice to order particulars of “false innuendoes” — even though, before 1974, they did not need to be specifically pleaded: Allsop v Church of England Newspaper Ltd [1972] 2 QB 161 at 167 ; Chakravarti v Advertiser Newspapers Ltd , above, CLR at 532; ALR at 302. But under s 9(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 the plaintiff's cause of action relates to each defamatory imputation, rather than to the publication as a whole: Petritsis v Hellenic Herald Pty Ltd [1978] 2 NSWLR 174 at 190 . It follows, and Pt 67 r 11(2)(a) requires, that each separate imputation must now be specifically pleaded and this includes imputations that might otherwise be regarded as “false innuendoes” — (“false” because the meaning conveyed does not require knowledge of any extrinsic facts). However, the requirement for specific pleading does not prevent a plaintiff from relying on an imputation that is either substantially the same as, or less injurious than, the imputation pleaded: Crampton v Nugawela (1996) 41 NSWLR 176 ; Chakravarti v Advertiser Newspapers Ltd , above, CLR at 532; ALR at 302; Random House Australia Pty Ltd v Abbott (1999) 94 FCR 296; 167 ALR 224 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.20] r 15.20 Particulars in relation to statements of claim by corporations

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to statements of claim by corporations

p.text: The particulars required by rule 15.1 in relation to a statement of claim seeking relief in relation to the publication of defamatory matter about a corporation must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the plaintiff relies to establish that the corporation is not precluded from asserting a cause of action for defamation.
Subject to limited exceptions, corporations are precluded from bringing defamation proceedings:
in relation to causes of action to which the Defamation Act 1974 applies, by section 8A of that Act, and
in relation to causes of action to which the Defamation Act 2005 applies, by section 9 of that Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.21] r 15.21 Particulars of defamation defences generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 18; DCR Part 49, rule 17)

leg:heading.title: Particulars of defamation defences generally (cf SCR Part 67, rule 18; DCR Part 49, rule 17)

p.text: The particulars of a defamation defence required by rule 15.1 must, unless the court orders otherwise, include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish:
that any imputation, notice, report, comment or other material was or related to a matter of public interest,
that any imputation was published under qualified privilege,
that any imputation or contextual imputation was true or was a matter of substantial truth,
that any material being proper material for comment was a matter of substantial truth.
If a defendant in proceedings for defamation intends to make a case in mitigation of damages by reference to:
the circumstances in which the publication complained of was made, or
the reputation of the plaintiff, or
any apology for, or explanation or correction or retraction of, any imputation complained of, or
any recovery, proceedings, receipt or agreement to which section 48 of the Defamation Act 1974 or section 38(1)(c) , (d) or (e) of the Defamation Act 2005 applies,
the defendant must give particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to make that case.

If a defendant in proceedings for defamation intends to show, in mitigation of damages, that any imputation complained of was true or was a matter of substantial truth, the defendant must give particulars identifying the imputation, stating that intention, and of the facts, matters and circumstances the defendant relies on to establish that the imputation was true or was a matter of substantial truth.

The particulars required by subrules (2) and (3) must be set out in the defence, or, if that is inconvenient, may be set out in a separate document, referred to in the defence and that document must be filed and served with the defence.

Where the imputation pleaded by the plaintiff in accordance with Pt 67 r 11 is so pleaded in sufficiently specific terms, and the defendant has undertaken to establish the truth of that imputation, a request for particulars of that defence in general terms is permitted. It is usually unnecessary in these circumstances for the plaintiff to nominate precisely the statements in the matter complained of in relation to which he or she sought particulars: NRMA Insurance Ltd v Flanagan (NSWSC, Hunt J, 6 February 1981, unreported) at pp 1–3, distinguishing Marks v Wilson-Boyd [1939] 2 All ER 605; but see generally Hepburn v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 386 at 389–95 ; Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 at 328 .
Legislation cited in [15.21.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.26, r 15.21(2).

A defendant normally does not plead to the plaintiff's damages allegation in the statement of claim: UCPR r 14.26 . Consequently, in the absence of a rule such as r 15.21(2) , but nevertheless subject to UCPR r 14.26(2)(b) — the defendant would be entitled to lead evidence relating to mitigation of the damages claimed: Reiter v Publishing & Broadcasting Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 29 May 1981, unreported). (An interesting historical survey of the defendant's position in relation to damages in defamation litigation is given by Lord Denning in Plato Films Ltd v Speidel [1961] AC 1090 at 1133–41; [1961] 1 All ER 876 ). Under the present rule a defendant must give particulars of the matters relied on in mitigation. Particulars that merely rely on “the circumstances in which it is proved by the plaintiff that the publication of the matter complained of was made” are proper. But particulars limited in that way will not permit a defendant to lead evidence (either by way of cross-examination of the plaintiff’s witnesses or by specific additional evidence) in order to mitigate damages: Reiter, above, at 6–7.

A defendant who relies upon qualified privilege at common law should identify the nature of the occasion of qualified privilege relied upon: Leslie v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1970] 1 NSWR 707; (1969) 91 WN (NSW) 648 at 652 ; Packer v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1972] 2 NSWLR 68 at 78 ; though he or she need not identify the specific right or duty to publish, nor the specific interests of those to whom the publication was made, for which he or she contends: Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 at 327 . Where the defendant relies upon the statutory defence of qualified privilege afforded by Defamation Act 1974 s 22, see Sims, above, at 327–8.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.22] r 15.22 Particulars in relation to defence of justification

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defence of justification
Defence under section 15 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 15(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 must (unless the court orders otherwise) include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish:
that the imputation in question was a matter of substantial truth, and
either:
that the imputation in question related to a matter of public interest, or
that the imputation in question was published under qualified privilege.
The defence of justification under section 15(2) of the Defamation Act 1974 applies to the exclusion of the common law defence of justification. See section 15(1) of the Defamation Act 1974.

leg:heading.title: Defences under section 25 of Defamation Act 2005 and at common law

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of justification under section 25 of the Defamation Act 2005 or at common law must (unless the court orders otherwise) include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the imputation in question was substantially true.

The defence of justification under section 25 of the Defamation Act 2005 is in addition to, and does not vitiate, limit or abrogate, the common law defence of justification. See section 24 (1) of the Defamation Act 2005.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.23] r 15.23 Particulars in relation to the defence of contextual truth

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to the defence of contextual truth
Defence under section 16 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 16 of the Defamation Act 1974 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish:
that the imputation in question related to a matter of public interest or was published under qualified privilege, and
that the contextual imputations on which the defendant relies:
related to a matter of public interest or that they were published under qualified privilege, and
are matters of substantial truth.

leg:heading.title: Defence under section 26 of Defamation Act 2005

p.text: Without limiting Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of contextual truth under section 26 of the Defamation Act 2005 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the contextual imputations on which the defendant relies are substantially true.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.24] r 15.24 Particulars in relation to defence of absolute privilege

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defence of absolute privilege

p.text: This rule applies:
to a defence of absolute privilege under Division 3 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 or under section 27 of the Defamation Act 2005, and
to the defence of absolute privilege at common law.

Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of absolute privilege to which this rule applies must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the imputation or matter complained of was published under absolute privilege.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.25] r 15.25 Particulars in relation to defences for publication of public and official documents

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defences for publication of public and official documents
Defence under section 25 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 25 of the Defamation Act 1974 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the matter complained of was:
a document or record specified as a document or record to which that section applies or a copy of such a document or record, or
a fair extract or fair abstract from, or a fair summary of, such a document or record.

leg:heading.title: Defence under section 27 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 27 of the Defamation Act 1974 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the matter complained of was a notice published in accordance with the direction of a court.

leg:heading.title: Defence under section 28 of Defamation Act 2005

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 28 of the Defamation Act 2005 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the matter complained of was contained in:
a public document or a fair copy of a public document, or
a fair summary of, or a fair extract from, a public document.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.26] r 15.26 Particulars in relation to defences of fair report of proceedings of public concern

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defences of fair report of proceedings of public concern
Defences under section 24 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 24 of the Defamation Act 1974 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that:
the matter complained of was a fair protected report, or
the matter complained of was a later publication by the defendant of:
a protected report or a copy of the protected report, or a fair extract or fair abstract from, or fair summary of, a protected report that was previously published by another person, or

material purporting to be a protected report or a copy of the protected report, or of a fair extract or fair abstract from, or fair summary of, material purporting to be a protected report that was previously published by another person,

and the defendant did not have knowledge that should have made the defendant aware that the protected report is not fair or the material purporting to be a protected report was not a protected report or is not fair.

leg:heading.title: Defences under section 29 of Defamation Act 2005

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 29 of the Defamation Act 2005 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that:
the matter complained of was, or was contained in, a fair report of any proceedings of public concern, or
the matter complained of:
was, or was contained in, an earlier published report of proceedings of public concern, and
was, or was contained in, a fair copy of, a fair summary of, or a fair extract from, the earlier published report,
and the defendant had no knowledge that would reasonably make the defendant aware that the earlier published report was not fair.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 15.27] r 15.27 Particulars in relation to defence of qualified privilege

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defence of qualified privilege

p.text: This rule applies:
to a defence under Division 4 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 or section 30 of the Defamation Act 2005, and
to any other defence of qualified privilege other than any of the following:
a defence under Division 5 , 6 or 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974,
a defence under section 28 , 29 or 31 of the Defamation Act 2005,
the defence of fair comment at common law.

Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of qualified privilege to which this rule applies must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the imputation or matter complained of was published under qualified privilege.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15.28] r 15.28 Particulars in relation to defences of comment and honest opinion (cf SCR Part 67, rule 17(3)–(6); DCR Part 49, rule16 (3)–(6))

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defences of comment and honest opinion (cf SCR Part 67, rule 17(3)–(6); DCR Part 49, rule16 (3)–(6))
Defences under Division 7 of Part 3 of Defamation Act 1974

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of comment under Division 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 must include:

particulars identifying the material on which it is alleged that the matter alleged to be comment was comment and identifying to what extent that material is alleged to be proper material for comment, and
as to material alleged to be proper material for comment, particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that allegation.
if the defendant relies on a defence under section 33 of that Act — particulars identifying the servant or agent of the defendant whose comment it is alleged to be.
A defence of fair comment under Division 7 of Part 3 of the Defamation Act 1974 applies to the exclusion of the common law defence of fair comment. See section 29 of the Defamation Act 1974.

leg:heading.title: Defences under section 31 of Defamation Act 2005

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of honest opinion under section 31 of the Defamation Act 2005 must include:
particulars identifying the material on which it is alleged that the matter alleged to be an opinion was an opinion and identifying to what extent that material is alleged to be proper material, and
as to material alleged to be proper material, particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that allegation, and
if the defendant relies on a defence under section 31(2) of that Act — particulars identifying the employee or agent of the defendant whose opinion it is alleged to be, and
if the defendant relies on a defence under section 31(3) of that Act — particulars identifying the commentator whose opinion it is alleged to be.

A defence of honest opinion under section 31 of the Defamation Act 2005 is in addition to, and does not vitiate, limit or abrogate, the common law defence of fair comment. See section 24(1) of the Defamation Act 2005.

leg:heading.title: Defence of fair comment at common law

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence of fair comment at common law must include:

particulars identifying the material on which it is alleged that the matter alleged to be comment was comment and identifying to what extent that material is alleged to be based on true facts or material that was published under privilege, and
as to material alleged to be true facts or material that was published under privilege, particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that allegation.
See note to subrule (2).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15.29] r 15.29 Particulars in relation to defence of innocent dissemination

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defence of innocent dissemination

p.text: Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence under section 32 of the Defamation Act 2005 must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that:
the defendant published the matter complained of merely in the capacity, or as an employee or agent, of a subordinate distributor, and
the defendant neither knew, nor ought reasonably to have known, that the matter was defamatory, and
the defendant’s lack of knowledge was not due to any negligence on the part of the defendant.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15.30] r 15.30 Particulars in relation to defence of triviality

leg:heading.title: Particulars in relation to defence of triviality

p.text: This rule applies to:
a defence under section 13 of the Defamation Act 1974, and
a defence under section 33 of the Defamation Act 2005.

Without limiting rule 15.21 , the particulars required by rule 15.1 for a defence to which this rule applies must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the defendant relies to establish that the circumstances of publication of the matter complained of were such that the plaintiff was unlikely to sustain any harm.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15.31] r 15.31 Particulars concerning grounds that defeat defamation defences (cf SCR Part 67, rule 19(1); DCR Part 49, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Particulars concerning grounds that defeat defamation defences (cf SCR Part 67, rule 19(1); DCR Part 49, rule 18)

p.text: If a plaintiff intends to meet any defamation defence:
by alleging that the defendant was actuated by express malice in the publication of the matter complained of, or
by relying on any matter which, under the Defamation Act 1974 or the Defamation Act 2005 , defeats the defence,

then the particulars required by rule 15.1 in relation to the reply must include particulars of the facts, matters and circumstances on which the plaintiff relies to establish that allegation or matter of defeasance.

The particulars required by subrule (1) must be set out in the reply, or, if that is inconvenient, may be set out in a separate document, referred to in the reply, and that document must be filed and served with the reply.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [15.32] r 15.32 Particulars concerning damages (cf SCR Part 67, rule 19(2) and (3); DCR Part 49, rule 18)

leg:heading.title: Particulars concerning damages (cf SCR Part 67, rule 19(2) and (3); DCR Part 49, rule 18)

p.text: The plaintiff must give:
particulars of facts, matters and circumstances on which the plaintiff will rely in support of a claim for aggravated damages, and
particulars of any claim the plaintiff makes by way of:
special damages, or
any claim for general loss of business or custom.
Legislation cited in [15.32.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 22, 34, 35.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 15.10(1)(c).

Damages awarded in defamation proceedings are determined by the judge, they must have “an appropriate and rational relationship to” the harm sustained by the plaintiff, and are subject to a statutory limit for non-economic loss: Defamation Act 2005 ss 22 , 34 , 35 . UCPR r 15.10(1)(c) does not exclude an obligation to give particulars of a claim for general damages. A defendant is entitled to particulars of a claim for loss of custom, notwithstanding that a claim for general damages has been made: Andrews v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1980] 2 NSWLR 225 ; Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 474 at 484 . As to mitigation of damages see [15.21.10]
Legislation cited in [15.32.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Defamation Act 1974 s 46(3)(a).
(NSW) Defamation Act 2005 s 37.

Exemplary damages are no longer available in New South Wales in defamation proceedings (Defamation Act 1974 s 46(3)(a) , Defamation Act 2005 s 37 ) but the damages available to a plaintiff may be aggravated by the defendant's conduct after publication. The situations which may aggravate damages may cover a period both before and after commencement of proceedings (Praed v Graham (1889) 24 QBD 55; Gordon v Street (1889) 69 LJQB 51), but conduct by the defendant or its counsel at the trial which was done bona fide in the legitimate defence of the defendant's case will not aggravate damages: Steele v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1974] 2 NSWLR 348 at 367–8 . Conduct relied on as aggravating damages must be unjustifiable, improper or lacking in good faith. It is insufficient if the conduct is merely actionable by, and consequently distressing to, the plaintiff: Uren v Australian Consolidated Press Ltd (1965) 66 SR (NSW) 271 at 302; 83 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 229 at 258 ; Rigby v Associated Newspapers Ltd (No 2) [1969] 1 NSWR 729 at 739–40 ; David Syme & Co Ltd v Mather [1977] VR 516 at 530, 535 ; Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 474 at 497 . Cases in both England and Australia prior to Rookes v Barnard [1964] AC 1129; [1964] 1 All ER 367 and Uren v John Fairfax & Sons Pty Ltd (1966) 117 CLR 118; [1967] ALR 25 (Uren's case) should be read with care, as insufficient attention was previously paid by even the highest courts to the distinction between aggravated compensatory damages and punitive damages: Uren's case, above, CLR at 128, 152; Rigby v Associated Newspapers Ltd (No 1) (1966) 68 SR (NSW) 414 at 438–9 ; Bickel v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 474 at 496 .

A defendant is entitled to the following further and better particulars of a claim for special damages: (a) the precise nature of the special damages claimed; (b) the amount thereof; and (c) the basis upon which that amount has been computed: AB Parry & Sons Pty Ltd v KG Murray Publishing Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 10 April 1980, unreported, BC8000045) at 8. Particulars of special damages may include the loss of specified customers of the plaintiff's business or a specific loss of profits, but as much certainty and particularity must be insisted upon as is reasonable having regard to the circumstances and to the nature of the acts themselves by which the damage is done: Ratcliffe v Evans [1892] 2 QB 524 at 530 ; Rubenstein v Truth & Sportsman Ltd [1960] VR 473 .
